sentences.sentence: A weakened prime minister remains for now - but the odds are shortening on his departureAweakenedBoris Johnson probably suits the majority of MPs at Westminster.
Unfortunately for the Conservative party, those with the most to gain sit on the benches opposite.

Few voters know exactly what Labour and the Liberal Democrats stand for, but both parties think that many more Tory seats will be vulnerable at the next general election if Mr Johnson remains in post.
This is a reasonable belief.
The government is out of ideas andexhausted.
Tory despair is compounded by Mr Johnson presiding over an openly divided party.On Monday night, more than four out of 10 of his colleagues said that Mr Johnson should go.
That rebels could be found from all wings of the party, rather than in one organised faction, is an indication of how far the rot has spread.
Conservative MPs would no doubt keep Mr Johnson if he helped them keep their jobs.
The trouble is that opinion polls show that Mr Johnson is neitherpopularnortrusted- evenamong Tory voters.

The governing party is right to fear electoral retribution, one likely to materialise this month intwo byelectionswhere scandal-hit Tory MPs stepped down.With such backbench resentment, it is hard to see how Mr Johnson will get the 38 bills in his Queen's speech through parliament.
The prime minister has been unable to convince the public that he has the answers to household incomes being squeezed byinflationand public services being stretched tobreaking pointpost-pandemic.
His rhetoric of ready fixes and easy wheezes might have been funny once, but no one is laughing in a crisis.

Voters won't believe a prime minister who has repeatedly failed to tell the truth about Downing Street's pandemic partying.It will take more than a reshuffle to restore confidence in Mr Johnson's premiership.
He will fool no one with a rightward lurch that voters will see as a ploy tobuy off backbench discontent.
A programme of tax cuts and privatisation must do more than send the pulses of rightwing Tory MPs racing.
The prime minister is by instinct a deeply unserious politician.
With the NHSclose to collapse, Mr Johnson offers only bombast.
Comparing the healthcare system to a DVD movie rental service in an “age of Netflix” might sound adventurous in a press release.

But proposing bluster rather than detailed plans to deal with an NHS breakdown is likely to be electorally counterproductive.Conservative MPs might fret about the absence of anyone suitable to succeed Mr Johnson.
The cabinet lacks the courage to tell him to go.
But the prime minister is a dead man walking.
He survives because no one wants to be responsible for finishing him off.
This is only delaying the inevitable.
The betting is that the Tory leadership rules will bechangedto allow the prime minister to face another challenge sooner than next June.

The trigger for this might be MPs on thestandards committeedeciding in autumn that Mr Johnson misled parliament about No 10's partying during lockdown.Paul Goodman, the editor of the Conservative Home website,wrotesagely that it would be better for Mr Johnson “to go now as master of his own fate, undefeated at the ballot box … rather than be forced out”.
Unfortunately, these words will be unheeded.
The country needs new leadership, one that can produce policies, not just play to the gallery.
Mr Johnson is comfortable with lying in politics.
Despite agreeing on a customs border in the Irish Sea to get Brexit done, he nowimprobablyclaims he did not.
Mr Johnson was never fit to be prime minister.
He has not been able to face up to the difficult choices ahead.
Britain should be led by someone who can.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: A weakened prime minister remains for now – but the odds are shortening on his departureAweakenedBoris Johnson probably suits the majority of MPs at Westminster. Unfortunately for the Conservative party, those with the most to gain sit on the benches opposite. Few voters know exactly what Labour and the Liberal Democrats stand for, but both parties think that many more Tory seats will be vulnerable at the next general election if Mr Johnson remains in post. This is a reasonable belief. The government is out of ideas andexhausted.  Tory despair is compounded by Mr Johnson presiding over an openly divided party.On Monday night, more than four out of 10 of his colleagues said that Mr Johnson should go. That rebels could be found from all wings of the party, rather than in one organised faction, is an indication of how far the rot has spread. Conservative MPs would no doubt keep Mr Johnson if he helped them keep their jobs. The trouble is that opinion polls show that Mr Johnson is neitherpopularnortrusted– evenamong Tory voters.  The governing party is right to fear electoral retribution, one likely to materialise this month intwo byelectionswhere scandal-hit Tory MPs stepped down.With such backbench resentment, it is hard to see how Mr Johnson will get the 38 bills in his Queen’s speech through parliament. The prime minister has been unable to convince the public that he has the answers to household incomes being squeezed byinflationand public services being stretched tobreaking pointpost-pandemic. His rhetoric of ready fixes and easy wheezes might have been funny once, but no one is laughing in a crisis. Voters won’t believe a prime minister who has repeatedly failed to tell the truth about Downing Street’s pandemic partying.It will take more than a reshuffle to restore confidence in Mr Johnson’s premiership. He will fool no one with a rightward lurch that voters will see as a ploy tobuy off backbench discontent.  A programme of tax cuts and privatisation must do more than send the pulses of rightwing Tory MPs racing. The prime minister is by instinct a deeply unserious politician. With the NHSclose to collapse, Mr Johnson offers only bombast. Comparing the healthcare system to a DVD movie rental service in an “age of Netflix” might sound adventurous in a press release. But proposing bluster rather than detailed plans to deal with an NHS breakdown is likely to be electorally counterproductive.Conservative MPs might fret about the absence of anyone suitable to succeed Mr Johnson. The cabinet lacks the courage to tell him to go. But the prime minister is a dead man walking. He survives because no one wants to be responsible for finishing him off. This is only delaying the inevitable. The betting is that the Tory leadership rules will bechangedto allow the prime minister to face another challenge sooner than next June. The trigger for this might be MPs on thestandards committeedeciding in autumn that Mr Johnson misled parliament about No 10’s partying during lockdown.Paul Goodman, the editor of the Conservative Home website,wrotesagely that it would be better for Mr Johnson “to go now as master of his own fate, undefeated at the ballot box … rather than be forced out”. Unfortunately, these words will be unheeded. The country needs new leadership, one that can produce policies, not just play to the gallery. Mr Johnson is comfortable with lying in politics. Despite agreeing on a customs border in the Irish Sea to get Brexit done, he nowimprobablyclaims he did not. Mr Johnson was never fit to be prime minister. He has not been able to face up to the difficult choices ahead. Britain should be led by someone who can.
